Whether you're releasing other defendants, I haven't decided.
Many claimants were asked to aid in the clean-up effort, and many are furious that Feinberg, not BP, decided that the money they earned will be deducted from their compensation package.
Claimants say that means they will have essentially worked to clean up BP's mess for free.
Wendy Kaufman, NPR News.
As part of his jobs tour, President Obama will visit a bridge next week.
There's a bridge that needs repair between Ohio and Kentucky.
It's on one of the busiest trucking routes in North America.
It's called the Brent Spence Bridge and it connects Republican Speaker John Boehner's part of Ohio with Kentucky, home to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell.
Even if you've never heard of the Brent Spence Bridge, you likely own a lot of things that have been across it.
As Tana Weingartner of member station WVXU in Cincinnati reports, the bridge is narrow and the traffic terrible.
The gunmetal-colored bridge spanning the Ohio River opened almost a half century ago with an 85,000-vehicle-per-day capacity.
Today, it carries nearly twice that and is rated functionally obsolete by the National Bridge Inventory.
Jenny Bass crosses the bridge on her way to and from work.
When I'm heading to work in the morning, I'm going south, and coming home, I'm going north, so the traffic is usually in the opposite direction.
What does it look like in the opposite direction?
Stalled.
Stalled out.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Bass isn't exaggerating, says Mark Policinski, the executive director of the Ohio Kentucky Indiana Regional Council of Governments.
He says the bridge isn't structurally obsolete, it just doesn't function.
Traffic regularly backs up an average of three miles per day on each side of the river.
The double-decker bridge carries two interstates, including I-75, which stretches from Michigan to Florida.
Policinski says replacing the bridge isn't just a local problem.
Over 2,000 miles of that trade corridor crosses this little rusted ribbon of bridge across the Ohio River.

And unless this bridge is augmented in some way, not only is it going to cause congestion and more air pollution, but it's going to have a dramatic impact on the ability of this country to move goods north to south, particularly east of the Mississippi.
In fact, Policinski says, three percent of the nation's gross domestic product crosses the Brent Spence each year.
The route is only expected to get busier as the expanded Panama Canal pumps even more freight along the corridor.
It is a bridge that is a bridge to everywhere.
In the 1980s, safety shoulders were removed to increase capacity.
Mere inches separate the outside lanes from the edge of the bridge.
Even a small accident can snarl traffic for hours.
Commuter Alice Pope says crossing the Brent Spence makes her anxious.
If I broke down, there's nowhere to go.
If you're in the middle lane, what happens?
And I sort of have this weird fear that a truck's going to smash into my Mini, and I'm going to go into the Ohio.
Her concerns aren't unfounded.
Just a few months ago, a man died after being knocked over the side of the bridge.
He'd run out of gas and was standing on the bridge when a crash pushed him over the rail.
Stefan Spinosa is the Ohio Department of Transportation's Brent Spence project manager.
He says reconfiguring the bridge corridor carries an estimated price tag of nearly $2.4 billion.
There's bipartisan support for expanding the bridge, but no one knows where the money will come from.
Whether it's federal government, whether it's the state motor fuel taxes, that's still up in the air.
The president's job bill could have an impact, I don't know.
Even if Congress comes up with most of the money, states on either side of the bridge must find the rest.
Officials in Kentucky and Ohio say it won't be easy to make that happen.
For NPR News, I'm Tana Weingartner in Cincinnati.
I'm standing in Fire Station 4 in Alexandria, Virginia, and I'm standing in the fire station bay, which is the garage.
And here, we've got the fire engine and the fire truck with a hundred-foot ladder on it.
And along the side of the walls are all of the firefighters' jackets and boots lined up.
And essentially, this firehouse is just waiting for the alarm to ring.
When that alarm does sound, the chances are they won't be headed to a fire.
Seventy percent of our calls are medic calls.
That's Jeff Taylor.
He becomes a full-fledged firefighter this week.
He used to play fireman when he was a kid.
But if you ask him, when is the last time you guys fought a fire?
there's a long pause.
We had a car fire a little while ago.
Other than that, I'd say about four months ago was my last structure fire.
Taylor and the two dozen other firefighters here are still saving lives.
They're just doing it on a gurney.
Every one of them is an emergency medical technician.
It's a dramatic shift for a profession idolized by folklore and the movies.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""BACKDRAFT"")
That's the movie ""Backdraft,"" which firefighters obsess about.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""BACKDRAFT"")
(as character) It's in the walls.
He means a Santa who looked like the children of the 7th Ward - black.
That's a difficult one to say.
I think that from the point of it as a large, national IT kind of project, yes, it is.
From the point of view as a potential uncertainty, in how the system is going work, and what kind of services will be, will people be able to use on the end of these I.D.
cards, that's really not fully specified as yet.
Hmm.
But there's lots of intentions and aspirations, but no certainty.
Has anybody done a test, a trial, of these biometric, of this biometric data?
How well it works in practice?
Ah, yes.
There are plenty of trials around, but nothing on the kind of scale that would be needed for a national I.D.
card.
The nearest is a trial in the Middle East, where, I think it's in Oman.
People going through immigration gates have an iris scan, which appears to be of its own the most accurate biometric technology.
And they're compared with a database, so that desirable people are let into the country, but those with a previous record of some criminal activity can be excluded.
And Oman, of course, a nation quite a bit smaller than Britain.
Absolutely.
And this would also cost a fair amount, you would think.
Well, there are varying estimates of the costs, ranging from something like 580 million pounds per year, to a staggering 19 billion pounds.
So I think that, that just reflects the uncertainty over the scale of the system that the government is planning to implement in the short term.
Mm-hmm.
Obviously, pounds are not the measure of money we use in this country, but that, either way, that's a lot of money.
Dollars terms, about a million, I'm sorry, a billion dollars per year on running costs.
And the maximum would be in the region of $35 billion on its largest estimate.
Now, is there also a plan that's been developed on how to get everybody in the country to register this information?
Yes, there's a plan to set up enrollment centers locally, which could be high street located.
Also, mobile vans would have equipment onboard enabling people to go up and register.
And this data collection would be carried out over a period of probably four years.
And would the, I guess there has be an end point, after which there would consequences if you're not registered.
Well, it's not at the moment a compulsory scheme.
That's been a concession that the government has made.
However, after 2008, as I understand the bill, it will be compulsory to have an I.D.
card if you're going to get a passport, as well.
So, you might not have to get, but if you want to go over to France, or well, I guess you don't need a passport to go to France.
But...
We do at the moment because Britain is not what is called a Schengen country.
There are some categorizations of European countries.
Many of the mainland of European countries, you can enter with their own national I.D.
cards.
And most European countries do have some kind of national I.D.
card, although that's not an electronic one.
Mm-hmm.
